title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: What we talk about when we talk about disruptions in spatial data science
text:
What we talk about when we talk about disruptions in spatial data science

Obvious disruptions
Other, less obvious, disruptions
A secret third type of disruptions that keep Rachel up at night

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: Some obvious disruptions
text:
Some obvious disruptions

Data—new, big, at scale
Methods—AI, GeoAI, Spatial Data Science, Urban Analytics, etc
Computational ease—real time, multiscalar, at scale




my guess is we will discuss these exhaustively

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: Other less obvious disruptions
text:
Other less obvious disruptions

Openness—for better…and maybe (?) sometimes for worse…
Closure—of state borders, as well as data access and ownership
Inclusion—the who, what, and where of research




what matters more: what we do or how we do it? (answer: both)

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: Disruptions that keep Rachel up at night
text:
Disruptions that keep Rachel up at night

Data disappearance—the old and the new
Conceptual + ontological drift—whether we’re measuring what we think we’re measuring*
Easy science—separating the scientific wheat from the chaff




*many of the basic precepts we organise our data and methods around are rapidly evolving: e.g., gender, household structure, place of work, employment, race/ethnicity

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: Distinguishing between disruptive science and science disruption
text: Distinguishing between disruptive science and science disruption

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: What can go wrong when we privilege disruptive science
text:
What can go wrong when we privilege disruptive science
makers versus carers
breakers versus maintainers

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: The mischaracterisation of political/social problems as research problems
text:
The mischaracterisation of political/social problems as research problems
time, resources, and policy attention devoted to technical and research investment rather than investment in actual change

title: Disruptions, Engagement, and GIScience Solutions
section: GIScience solutions
text:
GIScience solutions

Answer is more than more AI or more openness or more new names
A piece of the answer is definitely data, however
Knowing when to stay in our lane and when to swerve
And policy
And disciplinary solidarity




Aligning what’s good for careers, what’s good for science, and what’s good for the world

title: A Few Recent Talks
text: Spatial Data Science in an Age of Disruption, UC Santa Barbara, December 2023

title: Literature Reviews:
section: First things first
text:
First things first
Why do we do literature reviews? Who are they for and what purpose do they serve?

We do them because they’re expected
We do them for ourselves
We do them for others in the field—they’re an integral component of a research road map
All of the above

title: Literature Reviews:
text: source: xkcd.com/2281/

title: Literature Reviews:
section: Research Road Map: The Elements of a Paper
text:
Research Road Map: The Elements of a Paper

Introduction

Where you convince yourself and others of the what, why, and how of your research
This is three parts motivation, justification, and promotion

Literature Review/Background
Data and Methods—These elements are like a recipe; can someone cook the same research meal from your description?
Analysis and Discussion—Not only what you did (the analysis), but what you found!
Conclusions—Brief synopsis of what you’ve done, but mostly main takeaways (main findings, contribution to the literature, policy relevance, caveats, future research)

title: Literature Reviews: Together we can learn to love tolerate them
section: There’s no one right way to do a Lit Review
text:
There’s no one right way to do a Lit Review

The more you read and the more you practice, the more you see there are lots of ways to successfully write a scientific work
The internet is useful for all things academic!

Read and discard what doesn’t apply to you

I find it most helpful to think of the literature review as a process, one that you undergo for your own understanding of a topic
Once that’s settled in your mind, the writing and the structure will come more easily

title: Literature Reviews:
section: What does it do?
text:
What does it do?

A literature review synthesizes and assesses what we know about a topic and how we know it
And also sketches out a place for the research you are about to describe

This may not be an obvious “gap”!!

Usually outlines the origin of the topic (e.g., seminal papers), reinforced with what others have done

May be variations on the general theme, replications in different places or with different variable or models, or exploring different functional mechanisms

Don’t forget the how: data, methods, variables

title: Literature Reviews:
section: Some questions we can ask ourselves
text:
Some questions we can ask ourselves

What questions are asked on this topic?
What do we know?
The mechanisms by which a phenomenon is hypothesized to operate and what previous research has shown
How are questions asked/answered?

Methods
Variables
Data



Are there disputes or equivocal approaches? How will you fit into these debates?

title: Literature Reviews:
section: The real question you may be asking yourself: Why do I have to do this?
text:
The real question you may be asking yourself: Why do I have to do this?

What we find in our research is dependent on how we framed the question in the first place

For ourselves, we want to lay out our assumptions, context, and expectations
For others, we want to help them understand where we’re coming from and why we do what we do (research question, but also methods and data!)

Knowing what has been found in previous research will help you to place your findings into a larger context later in the paper/thesis

e.g., “similar to so-and-so, we also find that X has a strong positive effect on Y”

To get ideas for model specifications, variables, possible challenges that may arise and how to avert them, interpretation of results, etc
It is not about establishing that no one has done what you’re doing ever before in history

In fact, life is much easier if you can link to some related research.

title: Literature Reviews:
section: How to get started (some ideas)
text:
How to get started (some ideas)

You’re going to need to read
A “snowball” approach can be easiest

Start with the one or two papers that you know are relevant and useful
The ones you know you would cite
Look at their references and read those (relevant) papers

Google + Google Scholar

This is not a quick approach! It requires time and skimming lots of papers until you find the good stuff!

Start to identify the main themes in your topic

Don’t organize around paper; organize around topic or theme!

title: Literature Reviews:
section: Last words of advice
text:
Last words of advice

When you take notes on a paper, keep track of what you valued it for

Foundational literature? For their methodological approach? For the niche/gap in the literature they identify?

When you find a really useful paper, have a look at their references!
Your literature review should not read like a laundry list of citations.
Have a structure in mind after you’re done reading and before you sit down to write
It’s ok to cite selectively, but be aware of who you’re including/excluding!
What if you can’t find any related research? You’ll need to be creative about establishing a broader context for your work
Keep in mind who your community of scholars is: what literatures will they be expecting you to draw from?
